quoteFirst: On the 1st, rises at 5:29 a. m., sets at 5:25 p. m.; on the 16th, rises at 4:56 a. m., sets at 5:24 p. m.; on the 30th, rises at
quoteLast: , sets at 5:23 p. m.; on the 14th, at 12:27 a. m., twelve minutes south of moon.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, April 1885
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: I lay stress upon the time--
quoteLast: --for that is the hour at which this history really begins. Then it was that a four-wheeled vehicle of a rapidly disappearing type drew up before the imposing front door of the house in Hill Street.
title: Araminta
author: Snaith, J. C. (John Collis), 1876-1936

quoteFirst: At four o’clock, as I think I have told you already, it was the old lady’s custom, if the weather was favorable, to take the air in her yellow chariot. Upon this momentous day, however, the elements were adverse; and at
quoteLast: , by the clock in the blue drawing-room, she was to be found in that spacious, somber, yet magnificent apartment. She was wearing her second-best turban, a black silk dress, and a collar of priceless old lace, secured by a brooch which was said to have been given to an ancestress by good Queen Elizabeth, who, for reasons of state, afterwards cut off the head of the recipient.
title: Araminta
author: Snaith, J. C. (John Collis), 1876-1936
